title: ILLUSTRATIONS FOR LIFE - 3
words:
Anger

Anger plagues us all. Thomas Jefferson wrote, "When angry, count to 10
before you speak; if very angry, 100.'' Buying time in a situation 
that angers you allows you to remember the times when you blew up and 
accomplished nothing; to remember how out-of-control, embarrassed, 
and exhausted you felt; to remember others' reactions to your 
anger-their fear, pain, and disgust. 1 Proverbs14:29 states a great 
truth: "A patient man has great understanding, but a quick-tempered 
man displays folly" (NIV).
--Keith Durso

Arrogance 

On February 20, 1755, Edward Braddock arrived in Virginia as 
commander in chief of British forces in America. War with France was 
on. His task against the French was simple, or so he thought: He told 
Benjamin Franklin that after taking Fort Duquesne, in two or three 
days he would proceed to capture the French fort at Niagara, and if 
winter did not come too soon, he would take Frontenac as well. It all 
sounded so easy.

Franklin cautioned Braddock about the danger of ambushes from the 
Indians along the nearly four-mile-long line. Braddock replied, 
"These savages may indeed be a formidable enemy to your raw American 
militia, but upon the King's regular and disciplined troops, sir, it 
is impossible they should make any impression." Even George 
Washington, Braddock's aide-de-camp, found reasoning with the general 
useless.  Braddock refused to take defensive measures and fight the 
Canadian French and their Indian allies as they should be fought. At 
about 10 o'clock on the morning of July 8, 1775, the British forces 
were attacked near present-day Pittsburgh. 

The battle was a rout. The British took 977 casualties out of l,469 
troops. Braddock was mortally wounded and died a few days later. The 
heaviest losses were to the Virginia Militia under George 
Washington's command. Only 30 men out of three American companies 
survived.


Bible

A minister friend  once met Jesse James and questioned him about his 
wayward life. He reminded Jesse that he used to read his Bible, 
whereupon the outlaw thrust his hand into his inside coat pocket and 
produced a New Testament. The minister looked through the book in 
astonishment. He later said that never in his life had he seen a 
Testament so marked up showing constant use.
-Lee Roy David


Blame 

Dennis the Menace, in his prayers one night, was talking to God about 
the latest problem he had been in. He said, "God, it wasn't really my 
fault, but I guess you hear that all the time."  Brian L Harbour


Communication

Translating one language into another is sometimes a risky task. Not 
only the words but the meaning must be translated accurately. 
President Carter set up a Commission on Foreign Languages and 
International Studies to determine how translating from our language 
to another is affecting our country's standing abroad. 
Evidently, an investigation is needed. For example, some car 
interiors marked "Body by Fisher" came across in some foreign markets 
as "Corpses by Fisher." When Pepsi was introduced into Taiwan, its 
slogan "Come Alive" was translated in Chinese, "Pepsi brings your 
ancestors back from the grave."
Persons today need to understand who God is and what he means to our 
lives. God in Christ translated the meaning of himself for us, "The 
Word became flesh, and dwelt among us" (John J:14). -H. Joseph Blair

Discouragement

Amid those alluring attractions for which San Francisco is famous, 
one stands supreme-the Golden Gate Bridge, truly one of the most 
monumental engineering feats of all time. 

This bridge is known for its tremendous towers, its sweeping cables, 
and its graceful span of 4200 feet. Constructed at a cost of 35 
million dollars, it would now cost upwards of a half billion dollars 
to replace today. More than 100 thousand cars a day bring in 7 
million dollars in tolls annually. 

For more than twenty years the vision of a bridge across the swirling 
waters of the Golden Gate lived in the mind and heart of Joseph B. 
Strauss, poet, dreamer, philosopher, engineer, and achiever 
extraordinary. He slept with it, ate with it, and worked with it. 
Bridging a mile-wide cleft in the Pacific coastline was regarded 
impossible, a problem utterly insoluble. 

That mile-wide cleft, through which the Pacific Ocean pours into the 
bay at San Francisco in turbulent ebb and flow of deep water, was to 
engineer Strauss an irresistible challenge. On January 5, 1933 
construction began while weeping Jeremiahs wailed, "It can't be 
done!" Never allowing himself to become discouraged by problems, 
setbacks, and difficulties, the bridge that couldn't be built was 
formally complete and opened to traffic on May 27, 1937. 

The sensational appeal of Golden Gate Bridge lies in two suspension 
cables, supporting a 4200-foot span of six-lane highway, each 
suspending the weight of 123 million pounds. Those two cables pass 
over the tops of the towers, terminating in massive blocks of 
concrete on shore. Thirty- six-and-one-half inches in diameter and 
7650 feet long, each cable contains 27,572 parallel bars the size of 
a lead pencil. Because of the strength of those intertwined wires, 
each cable has an ultimate tensile strength of 200 million pounds. 

Just as the union of 27,572 wires comprise the strength of the 
majestic Golden Gate Bridge, so you and I must be united in 
commitment to a splendid performance. 

Fanatics
A secretary said to an irate boss who had just raked her over the 
coals, "Of course I can spell correctly, but I'm not a fanatic about 
it." We need more fanatics for Christians-those who will not change 
their mind and will not change the subject. -Brian L. Harbour


Integrity

In 1804, a Kentucky Baptist congregation was split asunder because 
they could not agree about the right thing to do in a hypothetical 
situation. Someone proposed for discussion the moral question of 
whether a man, when captured by the Indians, was justified in lying 
to protect his family concealed nearby. Some declared that under such 
circumstances the man had a duty to lie while others maintained that 
he should tell the truth even if it meant the sacrifice of his 
family. The argument was so vehement that the church split into two 
congregations known as the Lying Baptists and the Truthful Baptists. 

The application of Christian principles to life situations is not 
always a simple consideration. Each individual must diligently search 
God's Word for guidance and depend heavily on the Holy Spirit for 
strength to maintain his integrity before God and man.  Lee Roy Davis

Missons

Being a missionary has nothing to do with geography. A missionary is 
not someone who lives outside the boundaries of his own country for 
Christ, but someone who lives outside the boundaries of his own self 
for Christ. - Bob Dixon

Every heart with Christ is a missionary and every heart without 
Christ is a mission field. - Dick Hillis
topics:
ANGER
ARROGANCE
BIBLE
JESSE JAMES
BLAMING OTHERS
PRAYER
DENNIS THE MENACE
COMMUNICATION
MISSIONS
BAPTISTS

title: ILLUSTRATIONS FOR LIFE 4
words:
Work - Labor

Reflect on your work until you discover reasons for enjoying it; 
learn to love whatever your engagement with life might be. If you 
cannot do this, switch jobs! For pride in your work is the first step 
toward joy in your life. In a word, find out what your uniqueness is 
and go to it. Excel!  Leonard E. Read

Life is a grindstone, and whether it grinds a man down or polishes 
him up depends on the stuff hes made of.  Josh Billings 

The surest way to go broke is to sit and wait for a break. 

Man must work. That is certain as the sun. But he may work grudgingly 
or he may work gratefully; he may work as a man, or he may work as a 
machine. There is no work so rude that he may not exalt it; no work 
so impassive that he may not breathe a soul into it; no work so dull 
that he may not enliven it. - Henry Giles

Though little, the master word looms large in meaning. It is the open 
sesame to every portal, the great equalizer, the philosopher's stove 
which transmutes all base metal of humanity into gold. The stupid it 
will make bright; the bright, brilliant; and the brilliant, steady. 
To youth it brings hope; to the middle aged, confidence; to the aged, 
repose. It's directly responsible for all advances in medicine during 
the past twenty-five years. Not only has it been the touchstone of 
progress, but it is the measure of success in everyday life and the 
master word is work. - William Osler

Bible

Reading the Word of God is like eating food-it is not the quantity 
eaten that contributes to strength and growth, but what has been 
digested. It is when we have so read that Word as to embody its 
thoughts and words and meaning in our prayers, and its principles in' 
our conduct, that we may be said to have read it to purpose; not till 
then."


The Bible seems to me like a river of light flowing through my 
darkness and it has kept my hope of accomplishments bright when 
things seemed too difficult to overcome. - Helen Keller


Was the sermon related to the text? Did you get the main idea of the 
sermon? Was the sermon material simple or complicated? Do I need to 
simplify the language? Do I need more illustrations? Was the sermon 
helpful to the needs of the congregation? Do I have some personal 
habits of voice or gestures which might dis-tract from God's message?


Persistence Pays 

Persistence pays. Charles Darrow proved that in the early thirties 
after his invention of the Monopoly game which the commercial game 
companies refused to manufacture. Parker Brothers scoffed at his 
creation. Their experts listed fifty-two major reasons why the game 
would not sell. A few years passed. 
In desperation Darrow finally produced his own homemade copies and 
convinced Wanamaker's Department Store in Philadelphia to accept them 
on a no-risk consignment. That was the Christmas of 1934. Monopoly 
became an instant sensation and caused an immediate memory loss among 
the Parker experts. They forgot about those fifty-two errors and 
rushed into production! 

Darrow became a millionaire many times over. Even today his family 
collects royalties from approximately ninety million sets sold 
annually. But the story could have ended differently without stubborn 
determination to stay with the dream and swim against the current. 
Persistence pays!


Shortcut and Shortchanged 

Some bargains aren't so cheap after all. A young man with a toothache 
went to a retired dentist reputed to charge only $3 per visit. Five 
minutes later the patient walked out minus his tooth. 
Of course, the patient first protested that the offending tooth might 
be filled; but it was too late. The old man replied with more tug 
than tact: "Back in my day we didn't learn to fill 'em. For $3 I'm 
just a pullin' dentist." 

A few years later the young man spent over $100 having that tooth 
re-placed by a competent dentist. Fortunately, modern dentists stress 
the value of preventive care for teeth. It's really much cheaper in 
the long run. 

Life is like that. We take shortcuts and find ourselves shortchanged. 
The easiest path usually has a high cost at the other end. 

Nowadays people seem to believe anything goes - except the Ten 
Commandments. It's easier to ignore them, but we do so at our own 
peril.


Without Compassion 

Forty years ago John Dillinger was the most notorious criminal in the 
country. His plight might have been different if some parents had 
been more compassionate. As a boy John Dillinger was arrested for 
minor crimes and placed on probation. He was sent to Sunday School. 
Parents of the other pupils in the class protested and threatened to 
withdraw their children if this "criminal" remained in the class. As 
a result, Johnny dropped out of the class. He never returned. In less 
than twenty years he was number one on the list of most wanted 
criminals. Judging from the sequence of events, that Sunday School 
class was the last opportunity society had to salvage a needy soul.

Lowly Presence

A pastor was waiting nervously for his first airplane flight. A 
sympathetic friend asked him: Didnt Jesus say, I am with you 
always? Doesnt that mean up in the air, too? Im not sure, 
replied the anxious preacher. All Jesus promised is, Lo, I am with 
you always! -L. D. Lindgens


Proverbs to Live By 

The following proverbs, which make excellent one-line illustrations, 
are taken from Proverbs to Live By, published in 1968 by Hallmark 
Cards of Kansas City, Missouri. 

A book whose sale is forbidden all men rush to see, and prohibition 
turns one reader into three.-Italian proverb
 
Four things come not back-the spoken word, the sped arrow, the past 
life, and the neglected opportunity. 

 Arabian proverb 

An empty vessel makes the greatest sound. - Shakespeare 

A lie has no legs, but scandalous wings. - Japanese proverb 

Conscience gets a lot of credit that belongs to cold feet. - 
Anonymous 


As long as the sun shines, one does not ask for the moon. - Russian 
proverb 
The fall of a leaf is a whisper to the living. - Russian proverb 

Once you have missed the first buttonhole, you'll never button up. - 
Goethe 
Perfection is attained by slow degrees; it requires the hands of 
time. - Voltaire 

Think not those faithful who praise all thy words and actions, but 
those who kindly reprove thy faults. 

He who sacrifices his conscience to ambition burns a picture to 
obtain the ashes. - Chinese proverb

The wise man has long ears, big eyes, and a short tongue. - Russian 
proverb 

If a man could have half his wishes, he would double his troubles. - 
Franklin 

Years ago an unknown and unnamed Negro in Salem, Massachusetts, whose 
wages were little more than a dollar a week, decided to give part of 
her earnings to support a Christian orphanage in Ceylon. Her gift 
went to pay for the care of Maria Peabody, a native girl. In the last 
year of her schooling, Maria came into an unexpected inheritance. 
This windfall came to her just at the time when the native Christians 
were trying to scrape money together to buy land and to build a 
church. Maria's immediate response was to turn all that she had 
received over to the little band of Christians that they might build 
their church. Who can say but that the meager gift that dedicated 
Negro Christian woman in Salem, Massachusetts, gave had been 
multiplied when it was given in Christ's name until now it had built 
a church in Ceylon.


One day King Louis XI of France, in a moment he thought himself most 
pious, made 'a solemn deed of covenant' conveying the entire province 
of Boulogne to the Virgin Mary. It was to be a pledge of love of 
Louis for God. But-note this--he reserved 'all the revenues thereof 
for himself."'

How can you call a man free when, his pleasures rule over him?  
Socrates

Man is not free who is not master of himself.  Epictetus

None are more hopelessly enslaved than those who falsely believe they 
are free. - Von Goethe

There are two freedoms, the false one where one is free to do what he 
likes, and the true where a man is free to do what he ought - Charles 
Kingsley

Adlai Stevenson once observed that there are two great flaws in many 
modern Americans' concept of freedom: We have assumed that freedom 
means a common viewpoint, while in truth freedom rings where opinions 
clash. We have confused the free with the free and easy.

title: ILLUSTRATIONS FOR LIFE 5
words:
Freedom

The philosophers suggest there are two kinds of freedom: negative 
freedom and positive freedom. Negative freedom is the absence of 
restraint and coercion. It is a "freedom from." According to the 
negative definition of freedom, a man or woman is free to the extent 
that he or she can choose between alternatives, uncompelled to act in 
accordance with the will of another. Positive freedom is the inherent 
right to certain privileges and benefits. It is "freedom for," 
"freedom to," and "freedom of." So we speak of freedom of speech, 
freedom of association, freedom of assembly, and freedom of worship. 
Philosophical freedom is a wonderful thing, but there is a greater 
freedom: the freedom from sin and self which only Christ can give. 
"Ye shall know the truth, and the truth shall set you free" (John 
8:32).  Ron Kiser


 Oscar Nichols, a 585-pound prison inmate in Lexington, Kentucky, is 
suing prison authorities for cruel and unusual punishment. He 
complains that his prison cell is geared for thin people, and has 
declared that he will never get out alive unless he gets an 
air-conditioned room, better bathroom facilities, his own television, 
and housekeeping assistance. When informed by prison officials that 
he could solve his problems by dieting, Nichols responded that he 
would not diet unless provided with the "diet" of his choice: fried 
fish or fried chicken daily. Though in prison, Nichols insists on his 
"rights." Real freedom involves more than self-centered "rights" - 
the freedom Christ gives frees from the greatest bondage of 
all-slavery to self!


Grief

Do you know how a Persian rug is woven? While it is being woven, the 
rug is stretched on a large vertical rack. The master weaver stands 
on one side and his helpers, who do the actual weaving, stand on the 
other. All day they stay in those positions with the master weaver, 
the artist, giving the directions for weaving and his helpers pulling 
the wool and yarn. When a mistake is made, the master weaver doesn't 
necessarily undo the error, but depending on his skill, he will 
create a new pattern around it. 

Often, the new pattern is more beautiful than the original. At the 
end of the day, the helpers go around to the master weaver's side 
where they see for the first time the pattern they wove rather than 
the strands and ends of yarn which they saw all day. 

The grief process is like weaving the rug. When we are in the midst 
of the process, we are like the helpers doing the weaving who see 
only the bits and strands of yam. On the other side is the Master 
Weaver, God, and He knows the beauty which will emerge. Joe E. Trull


Hope

In December 1980 I attended a conference led by Karl Menninger. To my 
surprise, he spent his entire address talking about a simple Dutch 
woman named Corrie Ten Boom. He felt that her ability to excise from 
her life the hostility caused by the irreparable damage done to her 
and her family by the Holocaust was the best hope for sanity in the 
world. How could she forgive? How could she know that beyond the 
surgery without anesthetic that true forgiveness always is inner 
peace and harmony with former enemies? She had to be convinced of the 
outcome of such forgiveness to attempt it. The answer: Jesus Christ 
had forgiven her sins at the cost to Him of the cross. Having 
understood this and received His forgiveness, she could forgive her 
enemies and hold up such forgiveness as the hope of the world. 

How ironic. A Galilean peasant whom two politicians passed back and 
forth like a pawn has become the human community's best hope, and in 
these days maybe its last.  Fred McGehee


Judgment

Klaus Barbie was a German Gestapo officer who served in France during 
World War II. From 1942 to 1944, he was head of the Gestapo in Lyon, 
France, where he became known as the "Butcher of Lyon." 

On two previous occasions in 1947 and again in 1954, Barbie was 
tried, convicted, and sentenced to death in absentia for his war 
crimes against the French. Those crimes include the execution of four 
thousand people and the deportation of seven thousand French Jews to 
concentration camps. They also include the torture and death of Jean 
Moulin, France's most revered Resistance leader, who is believed to 
have died under Barbie's personal torture in 1943. Perhaps the most 
poignant and damning case against him is the deportation of forty-one 
Jewish orphans, aged three to thirteen, from one French village to 
the Auschwitz death camp. All in all, he is accused of numerous 
atrocities against the French, having personally ordered the arrest, 
torture, death, and deportation of thousands of Jews and Resistance 
fighters. 

Some of the victims of Barbie's tortures and imprisonments are still 
alive. They recall vividly his personal involvement in their torture 
and questioning by the Gestapo. 

When the war ended, Barbie fled Europe using Red Cross documents. In 
1951 he arrived in Bolivia, where he settled with his family. French 
officials, who still actively search for Nazi war criminals, 
discovered his whereabouts several years ago and brought him back to 
France to face the charges against him. 

It is interesting to note that Barbie was not expelled from Bolivia 
because he is a war criminal. Bolivia does not have an extradition 
treaty with France. Barbie was deported from Bolivia because he had 
used a false name, Klaus Altmann, to obtain Bolivian citizenship. 
"Be sure your sin will find you out" (Num. 32:23). -Isaac McDonald


Materialism

A contemporary fable tells of two flies walking alongside a lovely 
piece of flypaper. "What do you think of this invention called 
'Toughfoot'?" said the younger to the older. 

"I am opposed to it," was the instant reply. 

"How is that?" asked the younger fly. "I thought you were 
broadminded. Is it poisonous?" 

"No," replied the other. 

"Is it bitter?" 

"No," came the reply again, "it is rather sweet." 

"Then what is your objection?" 

Just then a neighbor of theirs flew and set down right in the center 
of the paper. "My objection," said the older fly, "is just this: you 
will never find our friend yonder in prayer meeting again. He thinks 
he owns the flypaper, but the flypaper owns him!  Joe E. Trull


Potential 

Recently, the World Press Review carried a quotation from the 
National 
Concord of Lagos, Nigeria. That paper reported that twenty-six lakes 
have been found beneath the Sahara desert. The American space shuttle 
"Columbia" determined by echoes it received that there are miles and 
miles of underground rivers beneath that arid land. It is sad to 
think of the people who are starving because those hidden resources 
have not yet been tapped. 
What spiritual resources lie untapped in every congregation?


Priorities

Paul Harvey reported that one of the first actions taken in the new 
year by the Beruit, Lebanon, city administrators was the passing of a 
law against jaywalking. A dozen different war-ring factions with 
weapons in their hands, grenades on their belts, and explosives in 
their cars; scores of people killed and injured each week-and a law 
is passed against jaywalking, which city officials admittedly cannot 
enforce. 

This is reminiscent of some people whom Jesus once accused of 
"straining at gnats and swallowing camels." 

Awareness of such happenings in our world might serve as a reminder 
that we too often occupy ourselves with such trivia. If indeed it 
does, the11 the jaywalking law will have served us well. -Timothy 
Alexander


Provision

A sports columnist on the staff of a major metropolitan newspaper 
once labeled some professional athletes as belonging to the "Yes, 
But" club. "You know the drill," he lamented. "Larry Holmes once KOd 
Muhammad Ali. Yes, but Ali was long over the hill! Roger Maris broke 
Babe Ruth's home run record. Yes, but his season was eight games 
longer!"' 

Many well-meaning people work diligently in order to achieve a 
measure of success and prosperity during their brief lifetimes. It 
can be said about a number of them, "Yes, but they have neglected to 
make provision for the eternal dimension of their existence!

Those who can give up essential liberty to obtain a little temporary 
safety deserve neither liberty nor safety." - Benjamin Franklin

The noblest gift of a free people is to offer that freedom to others.

Mission-minded churches

No church that isnt interested and actively at work in sending the 
gospel story to other people has a right to exist:

"It is a terrible thing to have seen the vision, and to be so wrapped 
up in its contemplation as not to hear the knock of needy hands upon 
our doors."-Phillips Brooks

TV and Bible Reading

According to estimates of researchers, the average person, by the age 
of 65, will have spent nine years of his time watching TV and only 
four months studying the Bible.


There are four ways to know the Bible. First, know its beauty spots 
 the great texts of the Old Testament and the incomparable passages 
of the New. Second, know its individual books  the content and 
context of each. Third, know its characters  the men and women who 
throng its pages and illustrate its truth. Fourth, know its 
structural ideals  from creation to redemption 

Convictions

In 1555, Hugh Latimer and Nicholas Ridley were burned at the stake as 
heretics in Oxford, England. These men were influenced by the 
thinking of Protestant reformers. They broke from the Church of 
England and tried to establish what we call a Protestant church. 

They were sentenced to be burned at the stake. Onlookers took down 
their last words. This is what Bishop Latimer said: "Be of good 
comfort, Master Ridley, and play the man. We shall this day light 
such a candle by God's grace in England as I trust shall never be put 
out." He was right. The light that shone through their lives still is 
shining today. These two men put belief into practice.  Don Aycock


Love

When 1 was about 12 years of age one my friends moved to a new 
neighborhood. It was not too far to walk, but it was not familiar 
territory. On a Saturday morning some of us decided that we should 
walk to our friend's new home. 

As we walked we came upon an unusual site. A house had been started, 
foundation and subfloor installed, then abandoned. The stairwell had 
no stairs. Small trees had grown up, some even in the dirt floor of 
the basement. We walked away with unanswered questions. 

The next time my parents drove past the unfinished house, I said, 
"Look Mom! What happened?" 

She said, "Well son, a young couple bought that lot so they could 
build their dream house. They worked hard in all their spare time for 
a while. Then something happened to their love for one another. When 
their love was gone there wasn't any reason to work." 

Now I know that true love has its ups and downs. But it is always 
durable. Paul wrote: "Love never fails" (1 Cor. 13:8).  David L. 
Brown


Death -- Last words

Religious News Service published an article that included the last 
statements of some noted persons. 

Edgar Allan Poe, master of horror, ingenuity, and action blurted out, 
"Lord, help my poor soul." 

Charles Darwin, the British scientist of evolution theory fame, 
confidently faced death with these words, "I am not afraid to die." 

Carl Jung, the noted Swiss psychologist, gasped these last words to 
his son: "Quick, help me out of bed. ... I want to look at one last 
sunset." 

Francois Rabelais, the French writer, as he was dying, said, "I am 
going to the great perhaps." 

Oscar Wilde writer and Irish poet, who lived his last years on 
borrowed money, made this final comment: "I am dying, as I have 
lived, beyond my means." 

Mark Twain, famous author, spoke his last words to his daughter: 
"Good-bye. If we meet ... " 

Al Jolson, entertainer, parted life with these words: "This is it, 
boys. I'm going. I'm going." 

Max Baer, once the heavyweight boxing champion of the world, uttered 
these words: "Oh, God, here I go!" 

Arthur Ford, famed psychic, departed begging, "God, help me!" 

Harry Cohn, a film producer, stated just before he died: "It's too 
tough. It's just too tough." 

Washington Irving, early American author, painfully said, "When will 
this end?" 

Thomas Edison, famous inventor, said just before he died, "It's very 
beautiful over there." 

Sinclair Lewis, the Nobel prize-winning American novelist, said these 
final words: "There, the sun!" 

Henry Ward Beecher, pulpit orator, said as he slipped away, "Now 
comes the mystery."  Jack Gulledge


Lord's Supper 

Ireland, during the nineteenth century, was afflicted by the potato 
famine. During that time many of the Irish people immigrated to the 
United States. A young Irish boy stowed away on an American-bound 
ship. The ship struck an iceberg and began to sink. The captain gave 
the "abandon ship" order, and passengers and crew got into the 
lifeboats. 

In the tradition of the sea, the captain was the last to leave the 
floundering vessel. He took his place in the last seat in the last 
lifeboat. About that time the stowaway boy came out of hiding. The 
captain ordered his boat back to the sinking ship. He went back on 
board and put the boy in the seat he had vacated. 

As the lifeboat pulled away from the sinking ship a second time, 
leaving the captain to go down with his ship, the captain yelled to 
the boy, "Son, never forget what has been done for you today." 

The Irish lad survived that ordeal at sea and eventually reached 
America. He grew to manhood in this land of opportunity and became 
successful in spite of many obstacles. In his later years when he was 
asked why he had never given up in the face of difficulties, he told 
the story of that night at sea and what the captain had said to him, 
"Son, never forget what has been done for you today." 

In the memorial supper the Lord Jesus commanded his people to never 
forget what he had done for them.  Hardy R. Denham, Jr.


Family

The second Sunday in September is Grandparent's Day. Erma Bombeck 
defined a grandparent. "They can always be counted upon to buy 
anything you're selling . . . from all-purpose greeting cards to 
peanut brittle ... from flower seeds to cookies ... from transparent 
tape to 10 chances on a pony. A grandparent buys you gifts your 
mother says you don't need."


Sexuality

Church historian Roland Bainton has given us helpful background 
material on how human sexuality has been viewed historically.
 
The biblical view was celebrative. Sexuality was to be received with 
gratitude as part of God's good creation.

The early church overreacted to the abuse of sex in the pagan world. 
They came to exalt celibacy as the ideal and to view marriage as an 
inferior state. It was considered merely a "remedy for sin." 

During the middle ages marriage was enriched by the idea of romantic 
love. That view is still with us. While it has made a contribution, 
we must remember that the essence of romance is the unattainability 
of the object of one's affection. A classic example of this is the 
romantic love between Queen Guinevere and Sir Lancelot in the story 
Camelot. 

The Puritan view of human sexuality was hush-hush. As that attitude 
carried over into the Victorian age, there was a lot of hypocrisy 
about sexual matters. 

The modern sexual revolution has brought a healthy openness about 
sexuality but greater permissiveness and a preoccupation with sex. We 
need to recover the biblical perspective which views sex as God's 
gift to be received with gratitude and to find expression within 
marriage.


Jesus and women

Whatever one's view of the ERA, it is useful to note that Jesus was 
the original liberator of women, men, and children. Indeed, he did 
more to liberate women from an inferior status and injustice than any 
other person in history. This is unique among the world's religious 
leaders. 

Jesus elevated the status of women. He treated them as persons and 
took their questions seriously. No act of Jesus and no parable he 
told was at a woman's expense. He never made fun of women or 
belittled them. Jesus' attitude toward women was revolutionary in his 
day, even among the Jews. The seventh commandment was originally a 
property law. To commit adultery was to devalue another man's 
property-his daughter or wife.

title: ILLUSTRATIONS FOR LIFE 6
words:
Women and Jesus

Women were prominent in the New Testament. Luke is called the woman's 
Gospel. Consider Mary, the mother of Jesus, Mary Magdalene, Mary and 
Martha of Bethany, Joanna, Philip's daughters who were in-spired 
preachers, Lydia and Phoebe. It is noteworthy that women were the 
first at Jesus' cradle, the last at his cross, and the first to 
discover his resurrection. How do we apply this truth to woman's role 
today?

Attitude 

It's human nature to worship at the biggest altars. But what about 
the little things? Are they not also important? 
One vote gave Oliver Cromwell control of England in 1656. One vote 
changed France from a monarchy to a republic in 1875. One vote denied 
Aaron Burr the presidency. One vote elected Thomas Jefferson to that 
office. Blinded by bigness, we earthlings often miss the importance 
of little things. But Jesus didnt. He spoke of the Father knowing 
when one sparrow falls. And it was the one sheep the Good Shepherd 
sought until He found it. Jesus knew the importance of little things. 
And it is a lesson we need to learn, for lifes sweetest symphonies 
are often played in the minor keys.  J.B.Fowler

Christs Return

When will the world end? Even the comic strip cat Garfield has an 
opinion. Garfield hates Mondays. In one sequence he sulks under a 
blanket with the thought, "I'm sure the world will end on a Monday . 
. . at least I hope it does. It would be a shame to end the world 
right before a weekend." 
Jesus said: "But of that day or that hour no one knows, not even the 
angels in heaven, nor the Son, but only the Father. Take heed, watch; 
for you do not know when the time will come" (Mark 13:32-33, RSV). 
-Bill D. Whittaker

Love

Herschel Hobbs, a former president of the Southern Baptist 
Convention, said that his father died when he was nine years old. 

It was 1917 and because of the war it was impossible to hire someone 
to help them on their farm. Hobbs' mother would plow the first 
furrow, laying out the rows for young Herschel to follow. She would 
then tum the plow over to her son. It was hard work and the family 
faced hard times. 

However, early one morning, the Hobbses looked down the road and saw 
a sight that deeply moved them. Wagons were moving toward their farm. 
The neighbors, for miles around, were coming to the rescue. And by 
the time night fell on their forty-acre farm, the ground was plowed 
and the crop was planted. 

Love did it. Christian love always finds a way to express itself. It 
is never idle. Although it may not say much, Christian love is always 
busy helping others.  J.B. Fowles


Relationships

We can live only in relationships. We need each other. 

A rather crude and cruel experiment was carried out by Emperor 
Frederick, who ruled the Roman Empire in the thirteenth century. He 
wanted to know what man's original language was: Hebrew, Greek, or 
Latin? 

He decided to isolate a few infants from the sound of the human 
voice. He reasoned that they would eventually speak the natural 
tongue of man. Wet nurses who were sworn to absolute silence were 
obtained, and though it was difficult for them, they abided by the 
rule. The infants never heard a word-not a sound from a human voice. 
Within several months they were all dead.  Joe E. Trull 


Sincerity

A busy convenience store in a North Carolina town had two signs 
prominently displayed in the parking lot. One of the signs read: 
"Open 24 Hours." The other added, "No Loitering After Hours." 
First-time customers usually stare for a moment before smiling at the 
incongruity of the signs. 

Honest Christians must admit that our churches often proclaim an 
equally mixed message. We usually claim that all are welcome in our 
fellowship. Yet, there are other, more subtle signs which indicate 
that some are more welcome than others. 

Do we truly welcome all people, all of the time? If not, the 
uncertain sound of our mixed message may draw the curious, but not 
for long. Christians, of all people, are called to sound a clear note 
of love and acceptance for all in the midst of a suspicious society. 
-Tony W. Cartledge


Tomorrow

Marquerite Higgins was a journalist who covered the Korean War. She 
was awarded the Pulitzer prize for her sensitive work. 
Once when she was with the 5th Company of Marines, she heard another 
news correspondent talking to an exhausted Marine who was leaning 
against a tree, eating his supper out of a tin can. 

"If I were God," she heard the reporter ask, "and could grant you 
anything you wished, what would you most want?" 

Expressionless, but carefully pondering the question, the Marine 
lifted his tired eyes and slowly replied, "Just give me tomorrow." 

When psychologist William Marston asked three thousand young people, 
"What are you living for?" 94 percent of them responded: "I am only 
enduring today. I am living for tomorrow." 

But not even Almighty God can give us tomorrow today. He only gives 
us one day at a time. -J.B. Fowler


Marriage

"A few phrases, used often, will keep the glow in your marriage. 
Learn them well, and use them whenever needed: I am wrong. I am 
sorry. Please forgive me. Here's what I appreciate about you. I love 
you."'

Note on a bulletin board: "The younger generation always seems much 
worse after you lose member-ship in it."

Busy

In the classic movie Beau Gest, the legionnaire fort was under 
attack. Only four legionaries were left alive inside, but they did 
not want the enemy to know how few they were. So the four remaining 
men propped up the dead bodies of their comrades and ran from man to 
man firing their guns. To the enemy it appeared many were firing 
guns, when, in reality, the fort was almost defeated. 
Many churches today present a picture of life by hosting many 
activities and events, often designed to give the appearance of life. 
The church at Laodicea said they were rich, wealthy, and had need for 
nothing. Yet Jesus said He would spew them out of His mouth because 
they were miserable and poor and blind and naked (Rev. 3: 16-18). 
Being busy does not please Goel; our obedience does. Let us return to 
reaching the lost for Christ, teaching them the things of Christ, and 
ministering to those in need.


Dedication 

This simple but wonderful epitaph is inscribed on a weathered 
tombstone in England: "In the worst of times, he did the best of 
things." 

The times we live in are difficult; immorality is rampant; many 
Chris-tians are lax; but your duty is to remain faithful. No matter 
how bad the times, do the best of things.  Mark Sutton


Dishonesty 

When the couple arrived in Las Vegas, the husband became fascinated 
by the casinos and started betting on all the attractions. After four 
days, they had just two dollars left. 

"Let me go to the casino alone," the man said. "I've got a feeling 
that I'll be lucky today." Once downstairs, he went to the roulette 
table and put his last two dollars on number 14, red. His number won. 
He continued betting and winning. Within an hour he had acquired 
$50,000. Feeling that his luck was about to change, he picked up his 
chips and walked toward the cashier. 

Just before he reached the cashier, he felt one final urge to bet. He 
went back to the roulette table and put everything on number 10, 
black. The wheel spun around and stopped on number 12, red. The 
fellow dragged back to his room. 

"Well," his wife asked anxiously, "how did you make out?" He said, "I 
lost two dollars."' You do not have to tell an outright untruth to be 
dishonest. Being dishonest can be telling a half truth or not all the 
truth. -Gene Jennings


Gods Standard

Dr. Roy Angel, in his book God's Gold Mines, relates an event from 
the life of President John Quincy Adams. President Adams called both 
houses of Congress together and walked to the rostrum carrying two 
bushel measures. The measures were considerably different in 
capacity. One measure contained 68 cubic inches less than the other. 

President Adams picked up two one-pound weights, the kind used to set 
on balance scales. One weight was an ounce lighter than the other. 
"Gentlemen," said the president, "we need a standard measure and a 
standard weight for the United States of America." Out of that 
experience was born the Bureau of Weights and Measures. Thanks to 
President Adams, an ounce is the same throughout the country. A 
gallon of milk in Wisconsin is the same as a gallon in Georgia or 
Florida. We need and have a universal spiritual and moral standard. 
It's God's Word. We don't have the right to set our own behavior 
standards that contradicts His revelation  Don Howell


Inheritance 

Patrick Henry, statesman and hero of the American Revolution, is 
known or his statement demanding liberty or death. More revealing of 
his character and faith is this statement: "My most cherished 
possession I wish I could leave you is my faith in Jesus Christ, for 
with Him and nothing else you can be happy, but without Him and with 
all else you will never be happy." -Rick Henson


Sawdust Trail 

The former major league baseball player Billy Sunday was an 
evangelist whose name is forever linked with "the sawdust trail." 
Billy Sunday held many of his services in tabernacles where the dirt 
floors were covered with sawdust which could be swept up and replaced 
to keep the building clean and sweet-smelling. 

Not too many people know the origin of the term "sawdust trail." At 
the turn of the century in the logging area of the Northwest 
lumberjacks would enter a dense forest to explore the best place for 
future log cutting. Since it was virgin territory no trails existed 
to enter or return from the forest. Instead of using a compass, the 
lumberjacks hauled bags of saw-dust on their shoulders. As they went 
into the woods, they left a trail of sawdust so they could find their 
way back to the point of entry. In that country "the sawdust trail" 
symbolized a route from dark, unfriendly places back to light and 
friends and family.


Wants or Needs 

A college student was perpetually late in getting her papers. When 
professor asked why, she said she was working two jobs. Knowing she 
had a full scholarship, he asked why she was working so hard. 

Im buying a mink coat," she replied. 

"A mink coat!" he exclaimed. "Do you need a mink coat?" 

She replied, "I want a mink coat; therefore, I need a mink coat." 

Allowing wants to become needs runs the risk of making necessities 
out of luxuries. This is especially troublesome in a world where over 
half of the population can't even get the bare essentials for 
survival. -James Evans


Hymn Stories

Many good books are on the market and in libraries, telling how hymns 
came to be written. One of my favorites is "Have Faith in God" and 
how it came to be written. It is doubly meaningful to me, for I heard 
the story from the composer himself, the late B. B. McKinney. I was 
attending Falls Creek Baptist Assembly in Oklahoma, about the summer 
of 1947. McKinney had just led us in singing this hymn, when, 
impromptu, he told its origin. 

"I wrote it in 1934," he began, "right in the middle of the Great 
Depression. I was leading the singing in a revival at the First 
Baptist Church in Muskogee, Oklahoma. Saturday morning, during the 
middle of the revival, I got to thinking of all the fine members of 
the Travis Avenue Baptist Church in Fort Worth, Texas, who were 
walking the streets, looking for work. 

"I was on the staff at Travis Avenue, and among other things, we 
served free meals in the church kitchen. Thinking of their struggles, 
I sat down and wrote these words and music": 

Faith in God

Have faith in God when your pathway is lonely, He sees and knows all 
the way you have trod; Never alone are the least of his children; 
Have faith in God, Have faith in God.

If you will turn to hymn 376 in the Baptist Hymnal (1975), you will 
note that Or. McKinney named the tune, "Muskogee," in honor of the 
city where it was composed.


Friends' Stories 

If we take time to listen, our preacher friends can share a wealth of 
illustrations. James M. Baldwin, an Illinois minister, and I were 
driving home from an associational meeting. He told me about the time 
when the late Ralph S. Cushman, a Methodist bishop, spoke in Salem, 
Illinois, where Baldwin was serving. 

One morning, the two ate breakfast together, and Cushman told him the 
story behind his poem, "The Secret." Here is Cushman's story, 
reconstructed in my words from memory: 

"Before I was elected a bishop," Cushman began, "I was pastor of the 
First Methodist Episcopal Church in Buffalo, New York, a prestigious 
pulpit. I got constant invitations to speak all over the country at 
business conventions, church meetings, and the like. 
"Often I'd return to Buffalo on the weekend, tired and unprepared to 
preach to my own people. One Sun-day morning, following my message, a 
dear layman, whom I had known since boyhood, stopped me. He had 
something to tell me, but it would anger me. Sure enough it did, when 
he told me the warmth had gone out of my preaching. 

"When I told my wife, she made me even angrier by saying she felt the 
same way but had hesitated to say so. By now I was so upset that I 
skipped dinner, going upstairs instead to my study at home. I 
remained secluded all afternoon, refusing supper, then stayed up all 
night, reading the entire New Testament. By morning I had found the 
secret-I'd been so busy preaching to others, that I had neglected my 
own devotional life. 

"I always liked oatmeal for breakfast, and the aroma floated up to my 
room. When Mrs. Cushman asked if I were going to eat breakfast, I 
said I'd be right down. But on an impulse, I first sat at my desk and 
quickly jotted off these lines"

The Wall  something there is that doesn't love a wall," wrote Robert 
Frost; and all the world agrees. Whereas some walls are 
useful-keeping in what is precious and fencing out what is 
feared-most walls are discouraging: "I ran up against a blank wall; I 
reached an impasse; I ended up on a dead-end street." Every day, we 
encounter some wall that brings us to a sudden grinding halt, that 
stops us dead in our tracks. Whenever we slam against a wall, our 
hearts bleed, even if our eyes stay dry. Our egos are bruised, even 
if our flesh goes unscratched. 

Walls differ in thickness, height, and length. But any wall deserving 
its name has one characteristic: It is indissoluble-you can't go 
through it. The ugliest walls are built of the stones of 
disappointment: We aim for first place but come in third. We bite a 
colorful apple, but it's sour. We lose faith in a friend, a cause. We 
learn we have cancer. We look into a mirror, and the image we see is 
not to our liking. We fail in business, lose a job. Our fondest 
dreams melt in air too thin to breathe. At times, we feel as if God 
Himself is blocking our goals, as the biblical writer said, He hath 
enclosed my ways with hewn stone" (Lam. 3:9). 

How many walls do we encounter in a lifetime? For a partial answer 
count the pages of a calendar, for no day dawns except a wall casts 
its shadow. No sun ever rises or sets on a perfect horizon. "When We 
Come to the End of a Perfect Day" is a lovely song but, at best, it's 
only a wish. 

However, it's no idle wish to believe that beyond every wall is a 
fair meadow, shimmering with goldenrod, purple aster, and red sumac. 
Neither is it a fantasy to believe that although we can't push our 
way through the walls that dampen our dreams, other vistas still 
unfold before us. 

Somewhere, someway, somehow, we can master the wall. 


Doubling Relationships

Wayne Oates told of listening, with a group of students, to a 
neurologist give a lecture on the brain syndromes and human behavior. 
The neurologist took the group to his laboratory and showed them 
brain specimen that had been taken from people who had died. 
Then in the midst of his lecture, he said: "The brain is nourished by 
stimulation from meaningful relation-ships to other people. And in 
the absence of this, the brain starves. We need to find the secret 
of adequate and proper stimulation of the brain by a meaningful and 
enriching community." 

"This was like a bolt out of the blue to us," related Oates, "to hear 
this from a neurologist in a pathology lab. -Joe E. Trull
Self-Centeredness

Some years ago in Mississippi, a doctor taught a Red Cross course in 
life-saving techniques and emergency medical assistance to a large 
number of ladies in the community. 

One evening a very serious accident occurred right in front of the 
home of one of these ladies. At the next meeting, the lady told the 
doctor that in the midst of that emergency she was so grateful for 
the Red Cross course. She said to him: "It was horrible-there was 
blood on the street, bruised bodies and broken bones. I was so glad 
to have had your course!" 

The doctor said, "Were you able to use what I taught you?" 

"Yes," the woman replied. "I put my head between my legs and breathed 
deeply, and do you know that I never even felt like I was going to 
faint!"  Joe. E. Trull


Talents 

In seventeenth-century Italy, in the town of Cremona, lived a young 
boy named Antonio. Antonio was often sad because he lived in a town 
that was famous for its music, but he could neither sing nor play. 
Antonio's voice was high and squeaky, so he was not welcome in the 
Cremona boys' choir. When he took violin lessons, the neighbors 
persuaded his parents to make him stop. Yet, Antonio still wanted to 
make music. 

Antonio's friends kidded him because it seemed that his only talent 
was whittling, but he did not give up. One day the boy learned that a 
world-famous violin maker named Amati lived in Cremona. The next 
morning Antonio went to visit Amati and begged to serve as his 
apprentice. For many years he studied and worked. Antonio's knack for 
whittling grew into the skill of carving; his hobby became his craft. 
Patiently he fashioned many violins, striving to make each one better 
and more beautiful than the one before. 

When Antonio died, he left over 1500 violins, each one bearing a 
label which said "Antonio Stradivarius." Today they are the most 
sought-after violins in all of the world. The clarity of tone and 
careful craftsmanship remain untouched by the centuries. Today 
Antonio's violins sell for more than $100,000. 

Antonio Stradivarius could neither sing nor play, but he did what he 
could, and now, over three hundred years later, his violins are still 
making beautiful music. 

Christians are sometimes concerned because they cannot sing or play 
or preach or even teach. However, the important thing is not where 
our talent lies, but whether we are using the talents we have. A song 
in the heart will surely find expression through some phase of the 
dedicated Christian's life. -Tony W. Cartledge


Louisa Fletcher wrote a poem, "The Land of Beginning Again." It 
begins: 

I wish that there were some wonderful place 
Called the Land of Beginning Again, 
Where all our mistakes and all our heartaches 
And all of our poor selfish grief Could be dropped like a shabby old 
coat at the door, 
And never be put on again.'
Counterfeit Christians 
A special group of men perform an important task for the United 
States Treasury Department. Their job is to track down counterfeit 
bills and those who distribute them. Naturally, these men must be 
able to identify readily fake currency. 
How are they trained to do this? You would think they'd study all 
types of counterfeit money being printed. No, that's not what they 
do. They spend hours with "real'' money. 
They come to know how the bills look and even how they feel. These 
agents don't have to know all the different types of "funny money." 
Because they are intimately familiar with the real thing, everything 
else stands out as false. 
We Christians do not need to be informed of every type of sin that 
exists. We should concentrate on getting to know our Heavenly Father 
better and living closer to Him.  Mark Sutton


Endurance 

As we watch the talented wizardry of basketball star Michael Jordan, 
we may assume his success came easy. However, Bob Greene, author, 
Time, reveals that at age 15 was cut from his junior high basketball 
team; but he didn't let his an early failure keep him from working 
and developing his skills.' 
Churches and church leaders need to learn to endure. The race we run 
is not a short sprint; it is a marathon. We need to keep on until the 
battle is won. -Steve McKown

title: INVENTOR OF VASELINE ATE SPOONFUL EVERY MORNING
words:
The inventor of Vaseline ate a spoonful of it every morning  

Sir Robert Chesebrough started his career as a chemist who refined 
kerosene from the oil of the sperm whales.

The discovery of petroleum in Titusville, Pennsylvania rendered his 
job obsolete, so he traveled there to research what new materials 
might be created from the new fuel.

This is how he discovered petroleum jelly, which he trade named as 
Vaseline.

Chesebrough had great faith in this product and before sending it to 
the market for the first time he tested it on his own cuts and burns.

He was unable to sell any to drug stores, so he traveled around New 
York demonstrating his miracle product.

In front of a large crowd, he burnt his skin with acid or an open 
flame, then spread the clear jelly on his injuries while 
demonstrating past injuries which he claimed had been healed by his 
miracle product.

His struggle finally paid off in 1870 when he opened his first 
factory and named the product Vaseline with a patent labeled on it.

Queen Victoria was said to be a huge fan of the product and used it 
daily, and in 1883 she knighted him for his scientific accomplishment.

Chesebrough was such a believer in Vaseline that he ate a spoonful of 
it every morning, claiming it was good for the health.

Given that he lived to be 96 years old, maybe he had a point.

title: INHERIT THE WIND--CHANGING BY STANDING STILL
words:
In Inherit the Wind, the two opposing lawyers, longtime friends but 
now adversaries, are sitting on the porch of the hotel where one is 
staying, and theyre talking over old times and how life has brought 
them to this point.  Brady, the prosecuting attorney who uses his 
literal interpretation of scripture as a weapon, says to Drummond, 
the defense attorney, There used to be a mutuality of understanding 
and admiration between us, Henry. Why is it, my old friend, that 
youve, youve moved so far away from me? Drummond replies, Well, 
all motion is relative, Matt. Maybe its you who have moved away by 
standing still.

title: IF THERE IS ROOM IN YOUR HEART...
words:
From 1958 to 1961 I was manager of Halls Clothing Store in Ft. 
Worth, Texas. One day I was talking with one of our customers whose 
grandchild had a baby which she either did not want to keep or was 
unable to keep; I never knew which. We learned that Social Services 
was going to take the baby and place it in a substitute/foster home. 
The grandmother didnt want to take the baby, and her reason was that

title: IMMACULATE CONCEPTION BECAME CHURCH DOCTRINE
words:
Immaculate Conception Became Catholic Doctrine
Diana Severance, Ph.D. edited by Dan Graves, MSL

Immaculate Conception, Virgin Mary
Declaration of Immaculate Conception

Pope Pius IX declared the Immaculate Conception of Mary an article of 
faith on this day, December 8, 1854. According to his pronouncement 
in Ineffabilis Deus, Mary was given the grace to be sinless at the 
instant of her conception. Sin was shut out of her. The teaching was 
controversial among Christians at large. Neither Protestant nor 
Orthodox accepts it.

In general, Christians insist that any major doctrine must be clearly 
backed up by some Scripture. Catholics require the same. Yet, as the 
Catholic Encyclopedia admits: "No direct or categorical and stringent 
proof of the dogma can be brought forward from Scripture." Edward 
O'Connor, compiling a massive defense of the belief went even 
further, acknowledging that the idea was not even a tradition of the 
early church, coming to the fore about only 1100 AD.

Scriptural Evidence of Immaculate Conception

According to O'Connor, the doctrine of the Immaculate Conception was 
"handicapped by the lack of any clear Scriptural evidence (or, 
even...any explicit patristic tradition) in its favor, but it even 
seemed to go counter to the clear teaching of St. Paul...and Christ's 
own declaration..."

What is more, many of the greatest fathers of the church and its 
"doctors," explicitly rejected the idea. How could this belief be 
accepted when it is not taught in Scripture, had at best a weak early 
tradition, and was explicitly rejected by theologians of the highest 
rank?

Was the "Mother of God" Sinless?

Although the early church recognized that God chose Mary for a 
special place in His plan, countless sources both east and west show 
that she was not considered sinless. However, in the eastern part of 
the church, some theologians did write of Mary as pure and holy. Mary 
was called the "Mother of God" and, in passing, some remarked that 
she had special flawless holiness. Gradually, in the western church, 
this belief became the assertion of an unfallen nature.

By the twelfth century, the idea of the Immaculate Conception of Mary 
was widely accepted in the Roman Church, although there was still 
strong opposition to the belief. St. Thomas Aquinas especially 
objected that "If the soul of the Blessed Virgin had never been 
stained with the contagion of original sin, this would have detracted 
from Christ's dignity as the savior of all men." Many others stood 
with him. Thomas recognized that if Mary were without sin, she would 
not need a Savior; the Bible would then be wrong in saying Jesus was 
the Savior of all men and that "all have sinned and fall short of the 
glory of God; there is none righteous, no not one."

The thirteenth-century philosopher Duns Scotus tried to sidestep 
Aquinas' argument by saying that Mary's freedom from sin was a 
privilege given to her on the basis of Christ's future merits.

Both before and after the dogma was made binding on faithful 
Catholics by Pius to be "firmly and constantly... believed by all the 
faithful," theologians sought for new arguments to justify the 
teaching. Theology is a progressive science, they said. The church 
comes to understand some mysteries only after pondering them a long 
time in its heart. Mary was compared to a second Eve, sinless before 
her fall. How could Christ be born of flesh that was at some point in 
time under Satan's dominion? they asked. They argued that just as the 
Holy Spirit set John the Baptist apart while he was still in the 
womb, so Mary, to an even greater degree was set apart. 

However, other theologians replied to all these arguments and raised 
other objections--for instance is it credible that Mary, a mere 
mortal, withstood all temptation when even Christ, the living Son of 
God, could overcome the gravest only by sweating blood?



title: INNOVATIVE ST. BASIL
words:
Innovative St. Basil
Dan Graves, MSL

Suppose a newly elected President asked you to serve in his cabinet, 
and threatened to fine you if you refused, would you turn him down? 
St. Basil, who died on this day, January 1, 379 (probable date), is 
said to have done just that. When Roman Emperor Julian asked Basil to 
join his court, he refused because Julian had turned his back on 
Christianity. Emperor Julian was so angry, he fined Basil l,000 
pounds of gold--equivalent to nearly $6 million dollars. Basil 
laughed off the fine as ridiculous, and reminded Julian that the two 
had studied scriptures together as schoolboys.

Although today less than 1 percent of the people in Turkey are 
Christian, in the early days of the church, Turkey, then called Asia 
Minor, was a center for Christianity. Basil was born into an 
upper-class Christian family in Cappadocia. His mother and 
grandmother took special care to bring him up as a Christian. Basil's 
family produced other famous Christians. His brother is known as St. 
Gregory of Nyssa, a remarkable theologian and writer; his sister was 
St. Macrina, who founded a Christian community on the family property 
and who convinced Basil to leave the law for the church.

After Basil gave himself to the service of the church, he became a 
hermit and founded one of the earliest communities of monks in the 
Mideast. Leaving his reclusive life, he joined Gregory of Nazianzus 
in preaching. When famine overtook Cappadocia in 368, Basil sold 
inherited property to help the suffering and to feed the hungry. In 
370, he became Bishop of Caesarea. Here he founded hospitals, 
hostels, and schools, largely financed from his own funds. Children 
were cared for, slaves protected, and the homeless given shelter.

Even before he became the bishop of Ceasarea, Basil was an activist 
on important issues of the day. He staunchly defended the deity of 
the Holy Spirit and the doctrine of the Trinity (that God is three 
persons in one being).

On January 1, we remember St Basil for his sound Christian theology, 
compassion for the poor, sick, and homeless, and as a man who was 
willing to stand up for his faith--even against the mighty Roman 
emperor.


title: ISAAC BACKUS FORMED BAPTIST CHURCH
words:
Backus Bucked Formalism, Formed Baptist Church
Dan Graves, MSL

What if you asked your pastor how you could be rescued from God's 
wrath and he said he didn't know? That is what happened to Isaac 
Backus. The Great Awakening was in full swing in America. Evangelists 
wakened Americans to realize they needed to repent of sin, and Isaac 
was afraid.

When his pastor could not show him how to get right with God, Backus 
went about his business. For weeks he prayed desperately that God 
would show him how to save his soul. He felt powerless and very 
frightened. Peace came one morning as he mowed a field. "I was 
enabled by divine light to see the perfect righteousness of Christ 
and the freeness and riches of his grace," he later wrote.

Backus was determined that no one else should suffer as he had by not 
knowing how to find salvation. He studied Scripture so that he could 
explain to others that Jesus took our sin to the cross with him and 
that forgiveness is ours if we confess our sins to God, believing he 
is able to restore us.

People noticed the young man's zeal. Backus was about 22 when he 
began to preach and 24 when a little "separate" church in 
Middelborough, Massachusetts asked him to be their pastor. Separates 
were those who were converted in the Great Awakening and left the 
established church thinking its ministers were cold fish who knew 
theology but didn't know Jesus Christ.

Aware of his great responsibility, young Backus pleaded earnestly 
with the Lord that "he wouldn't suffer me to settle down in any snare 
or evil way."

Backus would have stayed with the Separates, but when he changed his 
views on baptism, his congregation grew cold toward him. And so, on 
this day, January 16, 1756, he formed the first Baptist church in 
Middleborough. It is as a Baptist that Backus is famous. When he was 
born, there were only 1,500 Baptists in New England. When he died, 
there were 21,000-- many of them converted through his efforts.

Backus is most famous for his long battle against taxation to 
supported state churches. It is wrong to force a person against their 
conscience, he said. "In Christ's kingdom, each one has equal right 
to judge for himself." His recorded the testimony of hundreds who 
suffered harassment because they refused to pay the religious tax. 
These included several members of Backus's own family, who went to 
jail or lost their property. Once he himself was seized by a 
policeman, but someone paid the tax for him. Through letters, 
testimony and civil disobedience, Backus forced Massachusetts to face 
its religious problem. He made others aware of the situation, too, 
riding 1,200 miles a year on horseback to inform them about it. He 
printed pamphlets. But separation of church and state was not 
achieved until after he died.

Backus also had a hand in founding America's first Baptist school of 
higher learning, Rhode Island College (Brown University).

title: INAUGURATION MUSICAL PERFORMANCES
words:
Inauguration Musical Performances Are Tricky. But Lady Gaga, Jennifer 
Lopez and Garth Brooks Did Exactly What We Needed Them to Do

BY STEPHANIE ZACHAREK 

 JANUARY 20, 2021    TIME MAGAZINE

When Lady Gaga, the first performer at the inauguration of President 
Joe Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris, stepped toward the podium 
to sing, everything about herthat tropical-red pouf of a skirt, the 
colossal golden dove perched on her shoulder, that milkmaid from MoMA 
hairdowas a celebratory announcement: Welcome to the modern age! 
Though the road ahead is rocky, we no longer need to live in dread. 
Gaga, living completely in the moment, had arrived to point the way 
toward the future.

Inauguration musical performances, in their need to balance solemnity 
with jubilation, are always tricky propositions. But the Biden-Harris 
performancesfrom Gaga, J. Lo and Garth Brooks, performers from 
disparate backgrounds and different disciplinesstruck a note unlike 
any weve previously heard. Lets call it a sigh of relief building 
to a cheer of exaltation. Even the cloud-strewn blue of the 
Washington sky seemed keyed to the moment, and to this particular 
event, taking place in a spot where just two weeks ago a bunch of 
clumsy, if dangerous, insurrectionists took a run at democracy and 
failed.

Read more: Photographs From the Inauguration of Joe Biden and Kamala 
Harris

Jennifer Lopez was the centerpiece performer, but lets talk about 
her first: emerging in all-white Chanel, she projected the confidence 
of a woman who has worked her way to the top of her game. White, as 
everyone likes to note, is one of the colors of the suffragettes, but 
its also the color of working people (in machine-washable cotton) 
and the color of luxury (in dry-clean-only silk and wool). In this 
remarkable high-low J. Lo outfitreplete with a snowy jabot, possibly 
a nod to the garb of our founding fathersLopez sang a remarkable 
song, This Land Is Your Land. It was written in 1940 by Woody 
Guthrie, allegedly in a shabby hotel room just outside of Times 
Squarenot on the 6, but close enough.

For Lopez to sing this songa protest anthem but also an irrefutable 
declaration of belongingwith so much conviction and boldness is to 
bring Guthries intent and his dream full circle. This is an America 
he couldnt have imagined, so terrible in some ways, yet so radiant 
in others. Here is where Woody in his work shirt meets a dazzling 
Latina artist from the Bronx who represents, not just in terms of any 
monetary success but in her sheer awesomeness, everything that an 
individual is free to strive toward in America. Lopezs version of 
the song wasnt a reclamationyou cant reclaim something that 
already belongs to you. And as she segued into the song we sometimes 
think of as our second national anthem, America the Beautiful, she 
reaffirmed that sense of ownership and pride. In a breakout moment 
she shouted out, in Spanish, words that translate into One nation 
under God, indivisible, with liberty and justice for all. But you 
didnt need to speak the language to know what she meant.

She was a tough act to follow, and the guy who drew the short straw 
was Garth Brooks. Sure enough, walking out stiffly in his pressed 
jeans and cowboy hat, how could he be, after the heroic glamour of J. 
Lo and Gaga, anything but a disappointment?

And then he began to sing, a version of Amazing Grace that he spun 
out with deep tenderness, as if he were holding a nest full of baby 
birds in his hands. Democracy, as the late John Lewis told us, is not 
a state but an actit is something to be nurtured. Country music, Ray 
Charles and Charley Pride notwithstanding, is generally unfriendly to 
people of color, perhaps not by design but definitely out of habit. 
Yet itlike the blues, like jazz, like rock n rollis part of who 
we are and where weve been. And to hear Brooks sing this songits 
words written by a white clergyman, though it took on even greater 
power when it was adopted as a Black spiritualwith such care and 
modesty opened the door to a new world of possibility and hope. That 
he invited everyoneeven those of us at home, which was most of usto 
sing the final verse was yet another kind of reaching out. As 
Republican Senator Roy Blunt pointed out after the performance, it 
was hard not to recall another version of this song: the time Barack 
Obama, spontaneously and, with a capella bravery, launched into it 
during the funeral service for Reverend Clementa Pinckney, killed in 
the Charleston shooting of 2015. And now it became clear that when 
Brooks stepped up to the podium in his neat but ordinary clothes, his 
intention was seemingly to deflect attention from himself and draw it 
forward to the song itself. This was an act of humility.

Garth Brooks performs  Amazing Grace  at President Joe Biden's 
inauguration.

All of this, of course, came late in the ceremony, after Lady Gaga 
had made her own offering to the proceedings, a cover version of the 
worlds most unsingable song, The Star-Spangled Banner. Damn this 
song! With its anti-democratic intervals, its not made for ordinary 
people to sing. But Gaga is no ordinary person. Those who are invited 
to sing at inaugurationsamong the greatest of them were Marian 
Anderson and Aretha Franklinare vested with a special 
responsibility. What would Gaga, in her gorgeous yet out-there Maison 
Schiaparelli outfitan ensemble that, like J. Los, reminded us that 
elegance with imagination is the best, maybe the only, kinddo with 
our weird but also oddly stirring national song?

The result was audacious and passionate and a little wild, as if the 
idea of patriotism (the true kind) had been beamed from Earth to Mars 
and back again, as a kind of test. Then she reached the line about 
Old Glory continuing to wave valiantly, having survived bloody battle 
and hardshipa line that should be corny, but that still stops my 
heart if its sung the right way. Just as she sang, But our flag was 
still there, she turned and, astonishingly, with a sweep of the arm 
straight out of Puccini or Verdi or Bizet, directed our attention to 
the actual flag. Her intent wasnt just a subtext. It was a shout of 
jubilation and defiance. After all of this, our flag is still there! 
And how dare anyone even try to mess with it. Just two weeks ago, at 
this very site, a group of irritable, willfully misinformed 
self-styled militants sought to replace that flag with one emblazoned 
not with stars and stripes but with one mans name. Angry at the 
sense that the world was moving beyond them, they had no idea that it 
had long ago moved past them. And now Lady Gaga sings not for them, 
but for us, for everybody who chooses, with fortitude and optimism, 
to move forward into the modern age, in our cowboy hats, our hard-won 
Chanel, and our shocking-raspberry ballgowns. Come as you arebut 
definitely come.

INAUGURATION MUSICAL PERFORMANCES
LADY GAGA
JENNIFER LOPEZ
GARTH BROOKS
BIDEN INAUGURATION

title: I DIDN'T FEEL LIKE I HAD A CHOICE
words:
June 11, 1963: Tuscaloosa, Alabama on the University of Alabama 
campus. Vivian Malone, a young black woman, enrolled as a student at 
the university, but not without opposition. Federal troops were there 
to ensure her entrance into the school, but her way was blocked 
personally by Governor George Wallace. I saw that happen on the 
evening news; some of you did too. We didnt have the Internet, 
Facebook or any of that other stuff in those days. But the world saw 
that happen. Holding out for racism and segregation, the governor 
failed in his attempt to keep her out. Vivian became the first 
African-American student ever to graduate from the University of 
Alabama.

Governor Wallace came to regret his actions of June 11, 1963 and 
years later was taken in his wheelchair into the Dexter Avenue 
Baptist Church in Montgomery, and there asked the black people to 
forgive him for his hardness. The governor also regretted how he 
treated Vivian that day and sought out her forgiveness. He wanted to 
make amends before he died, and he wanted to meet her. Vivian did 
meet him and told him that she had already forgiven him years 
earlier. 

Interviewed in 2003, she was asked about this:

"You said you'd forgiven him many years earlier?"

"Oh yes."

"And why did you do that?"

	Her reply: "This may sound weird. (But) I'm a Christian, and I grew 
up in the church. And I was taught thatjust as I was taught that no 
other person was better than Ithat we were all equal in the eyes of 
God. I was also taught that you forgive people, no matter what. And 
that was why I had to do it. I didn't feel as if I had a choice."

           And what were those words I asked you to remember? 
Forgiveness is not an emotion, it is a decision of the will. As we 
practice the work of forgiveness we discover more and more that 
forgiveness and healing are one.  (Agnes Sanford)

title: IN HIS STRUGGLE, HE WROTE
words:
There was a man who wrote novels and stories and poems by the 
hundreds. Then he Joined up as a mercenary in a European army. His 
side was defeated, and he was imprisoned fully expecting to face 
death. Instead of whining away his days and recoiling from life with 
a complaint that God must not care, he began a novel. He finished one 
chapter and read it to his fellow prisoners; they liked it. He 
finished another chapter and read this one also to the prisoners; 
they loved it. He finished the book in the midst of all the 
discomforts, and the man, Cervantes by name, called his book Don 
Quixote, the idea from which the magnificent song, The Impossible 
Dream, came.

I will hold you because earth-side life is hard and weird and too 
much sometimes. I will hold you because life can be exciting and 
joyful and full of emotion and that is overwhelming sometimes too.

I will hold you because you deserve to feel safe and wanted and 
protected and cared for. You are all of those things and right now I 
show you that by holding you close.

I will hold you close because were connected. Im your fire mama. 
Youre my water baby. We need each other.

I will hold you close because its not my job to teach you how to 
live unspoiled right now.

My life adventures on flat lands, sea and mountains brought me right 
here to you. None of that brought me to my knees the way loving you 
has.

So, I will hold you. For as long as you let me. And I am honored and 
humbled by every second of it
topics:
SHEENA JEFFERS
I WILL HOLD YOU BECAUSE...
ARL ROBERTSON

title: I WATCHED MY BABY COME
words:

Sheena Jeffers
February 24 at 7:15 PM   

On Monday, I felt myself become a mama and watched the love of my 
life become a father.

Arlo Paul Jeffers Robertson was born 2/22/21 at 7:21pm weighing 7 lbs 
and 8.8 oz.

Our birth story is incredibly beautiful which I will eventually write 
down but right now I am loving more deeply than Ive ever known. In 
fact, what did I think I even knew of love before right now?!

As many of you know, we had planned a home birth and we educated 
ourselves on how to do that in the safest, most comfortable way 
possible. Monday morning I woke up not expecting to have a baby! But 
he had other plans.

We labored at home together, my husband and me, for 90% of the labor. 
Then, our midwife joined us and we made it all the way to transition 
when Arlo decided to present, unexpectedly, breech! His little butt 
came out first!

We made our way to Henrico Doctors just to be extra safe but we made 
sure to say: No C-section, no medication.

My midwife carried us through a vaginal, unmedicated birth while the 
doctor and the students he had invited into the room to learn (since 
unmedicated, vaginal breech births dont happen often or at all in 
hospital settings) watched on.

Twenty-four hours later, we are home and loving each other and our 
son more than we ever thought was earthly possible.

There is so so much more to this story. And Ill soon write it down 
because I never want to forget. But for now, Im loving staring at 
him and my husband and my body in awe. See Less
 with Stephen T Robertson.

SHEENA JEFFERS
